title: How to Purée Strawberries

parts.name: Making Strawberry Purée from Fresh Strawberries

steps.headline: Purchase or pick suitable strawberries.
steps.description: The strawberries should be in the range of ripe to overripe. Do not use brown or slushy in texture (as this indicates they have gone off and will taste bad).

steps.headline: Wash the strawberries gently.
steps.description: Place in a colander and run a gentle stream or sprinkle of water over to clean them. Use cool water and allow the strawberries to drain in the colander. Transfer to clean paper towel and gently pat dry.

steps.headline: Remove the stems and leaves from the strawberries.
steps.description: This is also known as "hulling". The stems and leaves are not suitable for adding to the purée as they will change the consistency and color and add nothing by way of flavor.

steps.headline: Cut the strawberries.
steps.description: The process of making purée is made easier by cutting the strawberries into halves or quarters; this is especially important if the strawberries are large. If the strawberries are small in size, you will need to judge whether or not cutting is needed; if it is too hard to cut them, then they should be left whole.

steps.headline: Place the strawberries in a blender or food processor.
steps.description: Process or pulse until a puréed consistency forms. Alternatively, push the strawberries through a fine sieve; this is more work but may be suitable where you wish to ensure that no seeds are in the purée.

steps.headline: Serve or use as needed.
steps.description: The purée can be kept covered in the refrigerator for up to two days. If you would like to freeze the strawberry purée, choose one of the methods below that include added sugar.

parts.name: Making Strawberry Purée from Frozen Strawberries

steps.headline: Thaw the strawberries.
steps.description: Remove the strawberries from the freezer and place into a suitable large container. Allow to thaw; this can be done in the refrigerator and will take several hours.

steps.headline: Transfer the thawed strawberries to a food processor or a blender.
steps.description: Pour in any juice that has accumulated while thawing.

steps.headline: Blend or process the strawberries.
steps.description: Pulse or blend until there is a puréed consistency.

steps.headline: Pour into a serving container or use as directed in a recipe.

text:
Making Strawberry Purée from Fresh Strawberries Purchase or pick suitable strawberries. The strawberries should be in the range of ripe to overripe. Do not use brown or slushy in texture (as this indicates they have gone off and will taste bad). Wash the strawberries gently. Place in a colander and run a gentle stream or sprinkle of water over to clean them. Use cool water and allow the strawberries to drain in the colander. Transfer to clean paper towel and gently pat dry. Remove the stems and leaves from the strawberries. This is also known as "hulling". The stems and leaves are not suitable for adding to the purée as they will change the consistency and color and add nothing by way of flavor. Cut the strawberries. The process of making purée is made easier by cutting the strawberries into halves or quarters; this is especially important if the strawberries are large. If the strawberries are small in size, you will need to judge whether or not cutting is needed; if it is too hard to cut them, then they should be left whole. Place the strawberries in a blender or food processor. Process or pulse until a puréed consistency forms. Alternatively, push the strawberries through a fine sieve; this is more work but may be suitable where you wish to ensure that no seeds are in the purée. Serve or use as needed. The purée can be kept covered in the refrigerator for up to two days. If you would like to freeze the strawberry purée, choose one of the methods below that include added sugar. Making Strawberry Purée from Frozen Strawberries Thaw the strawberries. Remove the strawberries from the freezer and place into a suitable large container. Allow to thaw; this can be done in the refrigerator and will take several hours. Transfer the thawed strawberries to a food processor or a blender. Pour in any juice that has accumulated while thawing. Blend or process the strawberries. Pulse or blend until there is a puréed consistency. Pour into a serving container or use as directed in a recipe.  Sweetened Strawberry Purée[2]

If the sauce isn't sweet enough, you can add a little more sugar to taste. A few drops of lemon juice can also be added if desired. Use as needed. This sauce can be refrigerated for up to one week, or frozen. Powdered Sugar Strawberry Purée Wash the strawberries in a colander. Remove the stems and leaves. Cut into quarters and sprinkle with freshly squeezed lemon juice. Place the strawberries and powdered sugar into a non-stick saucepan. Place over a medium heat on the stovetop. Cook until the water from the strawberries evaporates. Stir occasionally and keep an eye on it. Transfer the cooked strawberries to a blender or food processor. Blend or pulse until a puréed consistency is reached. The small seeds should be pulverized. Pour the strawberry purée into a glass or ceramic container. The purée can be used immediately or stored for up to 2 days in the refrigerator, or frozen. Making Strawberry Purée for Babies Use organic strawberries where possible, as strawberries can carry high pesticide residue levels. Ensure that the strawberries are fully ripened. Wash and cut the strawberries as outlined in Method 1 above. Strawberries may be washed with one part vinegar to three parts water to remove bacteria. Decide how chunky you would like the purée. For ages 8 months to 10 months, make the purée using either a blender or a food processor. For babies aged 10 months and over, a chunkier version of the purée is acceptable, and can be achieved by mashing the strawberries using a potato masher. Serve immediately. If not using straight away, transfer to a suitable covered container and refrigerate for up to two days or freeze.
